verse: So all Israel was listed in the official records of Israel’s kings.
The first to resettle their property in their towns were the Israelite people, the priests, the Levites, and the temple servants.
Those settling in Jerusalem included some from Judah, some from Benjamin, and some from Ephraim and Manasseh:

All those selected as gatekeepers at the entrances were two hundred twelve. They were listed in the family records by their settlements. David and Samuel the seer assigned them to their trusted position.
So they and their descendants were the gatekeepers guarding the Lord’s house, that is, the tent.
The gatekeepers were on the four sides: east, west, north, and south.
Their relatives came in from their settlements, from time to time, to assist them for a period of seven days.
Due to their trustworthiness, the four master gatekeepers, who were Levites, were in charge of the rooms and the treasuries of God’s house.
They would spend the night patrolling God’s house since they had guard duty and were responsible for unlocking it every morning.
Some of them were responsible for the worship objects; they counted them when they were brought in and taken out.
Others were appointed over the furniture, the holy equipment, the flour, wine, oil, incense, and spices.
Some of the priests blended the ointment for the spices;
and Mattithiah, one of the Levites, the oldest son of Shallum the Korahite, was entrusted with baking the flat cakes.
Also some of their Kohathite relatives were responsible for preparing the stacks of bread for each Sabbath.
The singers were the heads of the households of the Levites. They lived in temple rooms and were free from other service because they were on duty day and night.
These were the heads of the households of the Levites, according to descent. They lived in Jerusalem.
